Kick starting Android Development with Kotlin — Diving into Kotlin code

Content

  • Why Kotlin-ize your Android Development
  • Part 1: Kick starting Android Development with Kotlin — Setting up Android Studio
  • Part 2: Kick starting Android Development with Kotlin — Diving into Kotlin code
  • Final part coming soon…

Prerequisite

  • Read the previous articles to know about Kotlin
  • Knowledge of basic syntax and features of Kotlin
  • Understanding of Android development in Java (Basics)

Let’s dive 🏊

I hope you guys have learned basic syntax of Kotlin or probably your a quick learner to directly understand the Kotlin code for Android.

In this part we will look at writing some Kotlin code, do some comparison between the Java code and Kotlin code, understand some cool 😎 things in Kotlin.

I present you the MainActivity in Java

Here’s how the same looks in Kotlin

Let’s break the Kotlin code down to understand what’s going on

Inheritance

In Kotlin inheritance that is “extends” and “implements” keywords are replaced with a “:” and we are extending AppCompatActivity which is a Java class from Android Support library.

PS: We directly inherited AppCompatActivity, this shows interoperable nature of Kotlin

Null safety

Everything in Kotlin is not null-able by default unless explicitly mentioned with “?”. It indicates that the object can have value or not (null) and compiler forces us to take of handling the null condition of the object in our code.

The “onCreate” function in the snippet above has the following parameter / argument which is marked with “?” at the end.

savedInstanceState: Bundle?

To interact with a null-able object is really easy. In the previous article we saw non-idiomatic way of doing it, by placing an “if” loop.

The idiomatic way is using “?” question mark to allow you to use the object in case it value exists, otherwise it will ignore it and you’ll be safe:

// Idiomatic way
var context = Context? = null
val resource = context?.getResources() // Safe

But what in case I want to execute bunch of lines only when context has value?

// Lots of lines with context
val res = context?.getResources()
val title = context?.getString(R.string.title)
setTitle(title)
// A better approach
if (context != null) {
   // Smart cast, Thank you Compiler!
   val res = context.getResources()
   val title = context.getString(R.string.title)
   setTitle(title)
}
// Another approach
context?.let {
   // Execute this block if not null
   val res = context.getResources()
   val title = context.getString(R.string.title)
   setTitle(title)
}
// Yet another approach
context?.apply {
   // Execute this block if not null
   val res = getResources()
   val title = getString(R.string.title)
   setTitle(title)
}
PS: The “setTitle()” function is just fake function for the sake of example

Choosing an approach is all upon the situation. I personally like writing the “let” block or “apply” block (Yeah there are other approaches too).

Let block

  • It is a scoping function, use it whenever you want to define a variable for a specific scope of your code but not beyond
  • It can be used to test null condition (Shown above)
  • It’s extremely useful to keep your code nicely self-contained so that you don’t have variables “leaking out”.
  • Comes with standard library of Kotlin
  • It can be called on any type

Apply block

  • Pretty similar to let block
  • The code written in this block feels like is part of the calling type. Confused? Just look again at the code again and you’ll notice that we are not calling context.getResources() but instead we are directly calling getResources()
  • Comes with standard library of Kotlin
Read more about the standard library: https://kotlinlang.org/api/latest/jvm/stdlib/index.html
http://beust.com/weblog/2015/10/30/exploring-the-kotlin-standard-library/

What about else condition?

val files = File("Test").listFiles()  
println(files?.size ?: "empty")

You can have an else condition using the ternary operator or Elvis operator ?:

I know your saying that’s awesome literally AWESOME!
Read more about null safety: https://kotlinlang.org/docs/reference/null-safety.html

Properties and Fields

Kotlin maps getters and setters to properties. They are like fields in Java.

// Getting context in Activity - Java style
String title = getBaseContext().getString(R.string.title)
// Getting context in Activity - Kotlin style
var title = baseContext.getString(R.string.title)

We directly access the variable. Behind the scene, Kotlin is calling the getter or setter of the object.

Let’s dive deeper

In order to understand Kotlin, we will build a simple open source Count down timer Android app. We won’t look at UI code in this article, you can refer it from the GitHub repository.

The Count down timer app will store the start time in the Shared Preferences and show a progress bar in the UI. See screenshots.

Binding views

Before starting the timer we need to bind the views in code.

Looking at the snippet you can sense the familiarity of the code with Java.

PS: The way shown above is not the best practice. There is a super cool way to do this in Kotlin. We will look into it in the next article.

Utility functions

To store the start time of the count down timer we will need “SharedPreferences”. As a good design practice we will create Utility functions to store and read the start time from “SharedPreferences”.

Wrapper to save the start time into the “SharedPreferences”. We use the functions defined in the “PrefUtils”.

Did you notice we have directly declared the functions without any class? What? Are you serious? They are Free functions.

Free Functions

In Kotlin, functions or variables can be declared at the top level in a file (*.kt) without any class holding them, this is called as “free function or variable”.

Free functions are by default static in nature. They are like static functions in Java except without any class holding them. 
What makes them special is you can write free functions and access them from another Kotlin class or file directly (without Class name).

Example:

// Accessing the PrefUtils in Java style
PrefUtils.remove("some_key");
// Kotlin style
remove("some_key")
It’s worth noting that these functions come with access specifiers to control the visibility

When Expression

I’m sure you noticed “when” keyword in the snippet above.

In simple words

“when” is super enhanced and magical “switch” expression
when (x) {     
     1 -> print("x == 1")
     2 -> print("x == 2")     
     else -> { 
         // Note the block         
         print("x is neither 1 nor 2")     
     } 
}
Read more about “when”:
1. https://kotlinlang.org/docs/reference/control-flow.html
2. https://antonioleiva.com/when-expression-kotlin/

Let’s start the timer

Object Expressions

The CountDownTimer is an abstract class in the Android API. In Java we create an anonymous class while Kotlin handles the same using Object Expressions using the “object” keyword (Shown below).

mTimer = object : CountDownTimer(millisInFuture, intervalMillis) {
         ....
}

This is the final “MainActivity” for this article. The code is pretty basic Kotlin syntax and some features. In the next article, we will change a lot of stuff by including more features of Kotlin.

Repository

https://github.com/AkshayChordiya/timer-kotlin-sample/tree/v0.20

Conclusion

In this part we barely scratched Kotlin. I know after reading this article it feels like Kotlin is similar to Java and there is not much, that’s because the Kotlin code is written in Java style to ease the understanding. In the next article we will kotlin-ize the code and implement exciting stuff of Kotlin.

We will truly kotlin-ize the code in the next article and see the power of Kotlin in building better apps while having fun.
